From Indicator: A1 Emissions for five key air pollutants
To Indicator: A3 Concentrations of fine particulate matter (PM2.5) in the air
Rationale: A1 includes emissions of PM2.5. As well as being emitted directly, particulate matter can be formed in the atmosphere from reactions between other pollutants, of which SO2, NOx, NMVOCs and NH3 are the most important.

From Indicator: A1 Emissions for five key air pollutants
To Indicator: A6 Exceedance of damaging levels of nutrient nitrogen deposition on ecosystems
Rationale: Damaging nutrient nitrogen comes predominantly from ammonia (NH3) but partly nitrogen oxides (NOx) and long-range transport of air pollutants.

From Indicator: A1 Emissions for five key air pollutants
To Indicator: A7 Area exposed to damaging levels of ammonia (NH3) in the atmosphere
Rationale: A1 includes emissions of NH3

From Indicator: A1 Emissions for five key air pollutants
To Indicator: A4 Rural background concentrations of ozone (O3)
Rationale: A1 includes NOx and VOC emissions. Chemical reactions in the air involving NOX and VOCs produce the toxic gas O3.

From Indicator: A1 Emissions for five key air pollutants
To Indicator: A5 Roadside nitrogen dioxide (NO2) concentrations
Rationale: NOx emissions (A1) include NO2 so contributes to roadside concentrations.

From Indicator: A3 Concentrations of fine particulate matter (PM2.5 ) in the air
To Indicator: G7 Health and wellbeing benefits
Rationale: Long-term exposure to particulate matter contributes to the risk of developing cardiovascular disease and lung cancer.

From Indicator: A6 Exceedance of damaging levels of nutrient nitrogen deposition on ecosystems
To Indicator: B3 State of the water environment
Rationale: Nutrients are a major cause of water bodies being at less than good ecological status and also affect drinking water quality. Nitrates account for 65% of the reasons for failure for those groundwaters that are protected for use for drinking water and are classed at poor status. Nitrate enters groundwater from diffuse pollution on land (mainly water run-off from agricultural land) or is deposited onto land from the air.

From Indicator: A6 Exceedance of damaging levels of nutrient nitrogen deposition on ecosystems
To Indicator: D1 Quantity, quality and connectivity of habitats
Rationale: Nutrient nitrogen deposition affects the nutrient levels and diversity of species in sensitive environments, for example, by encouraging algae growth in lakes and water courses.

To Indicator: D4 Relative abundance and distribution of widespread species
Rationale: Nutrient nitrogen deposition affects the nutrient levels and diversity of species in sensitive environments, for example, by encouraging algae growth in lakes and water courses.

Rationale: Nutrient nitrogen deposition affects the nutrient levels and diversity of species in sensitive environments, for example, by encouraging algae growth in lakes and water courses.

To Indicator: E7 Healthy soils
Rationale: Excess deposition of NH3 on natural ecosystems causes nutrient enrichment and changes in vegetation and soils.

To Indicator: G1 Changes in landscape and waterscape character
Rationale: Nutrient nitrogen deposition affects the nutrient levels and diversity of species in sensitive environments, for example, by encouraging algae growth in lakes and water courses.

From Indicator: A7 Area exposed to damaging levels of ammonia (NH3) in the atmosphere
To Indicator: A6 Exceedance of damaging levels of nutrient nitrogen deposition on ecosystems
Rationale: NH3 emissions can be deposited in soils or in rivers and lakes, for example, through rain. Resulting nutrient nitrogen deposition affects the nutrient levels and diversity of species in sensitive environments, for example, by encouraging algae growth in lakes and water courses.

From Indicator: A4 Rural background concentrations of ozone (O3)
To Indicator: G7 Health and wellbeing benefits
Rationale: Ozone is a gas which is damaging to human health and can trigger inflammation of the respiratory tract, eyes, nose and throat as well as asthma attacks.

Rationale: Ozone can have adverse effects on the environment through oxidative damage to vegetation.

Rationale: Ozone can have adverse effects on the environment through oxidative damage to vegetation.

From Indicator: A4 Rural background concentrations of ozone (O3)

Rationale: Ozone can have adverse effects on the environment through oxidative damage to vegetation including crops.

From Indicator: A5 Roadside nitrogen dioxide (NO2) concentrations
To Indicator: G7 Health and wellbeing benefits
Rationale: Short-term exposure to concentrations of NO2 can cause inflammation of the airways and increase susceptibility to respiratory infections and to allergens. NO2 can exacerbate the symptoms of those already suffering from lung or heart conditions.

From Indicator: A5 Roadside nitrogen dioxide (NO2) concentrations
To Indicator: A4 Rural background concentrations of ozone (O3)
Rationale: NO2 is one of the precursors to O3.

From Indicator: E3 Volume of inputs used in agricultural production
To Indicator: A1 Emissions for five key air pollutants
Rationale: Agricultural sources make up by far the largest component in the inventory for ammonia emissions with cattle manure management, manure applied to soils and inorganic fertilizers each accounting for 20% or more of the emissions from this sector. Agriculture also contributes a small proportion to NMVOC and PM2.5 emissions.
